newsitem.title: USA: Trucks crash after floodwaters collapse highway.
newsitem.headline: Trucks crash after floodwaters collapse highway.

text.p: Raging floodwaters caused a large section of Oregon's main north-south highway to collapse Thursday, creating a deep hole that was blamed for three truck accidents.
Oregon State Police Lt. Gregg Hastings said a 100-foot-long section of Interstate 5 in Roseburg collapsed about 1 a.m. (4 a.m. EST) under pressure from the rain-swollen South Umpqua River.
One truck with three trailers drove into the 30-foot-deep hole, but its driver escaped without injury, while a second tractor-trailer drove partly into the hole, causing minor injuries to the driver.

A third, more serious accident occured when the driver of a tractor-trailer veered to avoid the hole and struck a motorist who had gotten out of his pickup truck and was trying to get away from the scene.
The pickup driver, identified as Trampis Gress, 25, of Roseburg, had to have his foot amputated at a local hospital.

The highway was closed in both directions for about six hours after the accident until workers were able to open a single southbound lane. Workers were trying to open a second lane for northbound traffic but had no idea when the road might be repaired.

Roseburg, about 160 miles south of Portland, is in the heart of a three-county area where Gov. John Kitzhaber declared a state of emergency this week because of heavy rains and destructive mud slides that killed four people.
